intro: Campylopus cerastoides, commonly known as the rock moss, is a species of liverwort found in various habitats across the Northern Hemisphere. It is a small, mat-forming plant that thrives in moist, shaded environments such as rock crevices and forest floors. The plant has a distinct, compact growth pattern with dense, overlapping leaves that are typically green or reddish in color. Its reproductive structures, called capsules, are borne on short stalks and release spores when mature. Campylopus cerastoides plays a role in soil stabilization and provides microhabitats for various invertebrates.
